## The Fox's Philosophy of "Taming"

In "The Little Prince," the fox introduces the concept of "taming" as "an act too often neglected" that means "to establish ties."(no content)What the fox means by "tame" is to "make friends" or "to establish a relationship."(no content)The fox explains this beautifully: "To me, you are still nothing more than a little boy who is just like a hundred thousand other little boys. And I have no need of you. And you, on your part, have no need of me. To you, I am nothing more than a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But if you tame me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique in all the world. To you, I shall be unique in all the world."

## The Process of Building Friendship

The fox teaches that taming requires patience: "You must be very patient," replied the fox. "First you will sit down at a little distance from me--like that--in the grass. I shall look at you out of the corner of my eye, and you will say nothing. Words are the source of misunderstandings."(no content)The fox also observes a profound truth about modern society: "One only understands the things that one tames," and "But there is no shop anywhere where one can buy friendship, and so men have no friends any more."

## "What Is Essential Is Invisible to the Eye"

This is perhaps the fox's most famous teaching. The fox tells the little prince that the most important things in life are nonvisible. Love, truth, and the soul or essence of another living being are all essential things that the eyes cannot see but the heart will know and understand.(no content)The complete quote is: "It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye."(no content)The fox's wisdom encourages the Little Prince to appreciate the intangible, emotional connections that give life meaning, emphasizing that the most important things in life—like love, friendship, and loyalty—are not visible but felt with the heart.

## The Transformation Through Friendship

The fox describes how taming transforms life: "But if you tame me, it will be as if the sun came to shine on my life. I shall know the sound of a step that will be different from all the others. Yours will call me, like music, out of my burrow."(no content)The fox continues with the wheat field metaphor: "And then look: you see the grain-fields down yonder? I do not eat bread. Wheat is of no use to me. The wheat fields have nothing to say to me. And that is sad. But you have hair that is the color of gold. Think how wonderful that will be when you have tamed me! The grain, which is also golden, will bring me back the thought of you. And I shall love to listen to the wind in the wheat."

## The Philosophy of Responsibility and Time

The fox teaches that "It is the time you have wasted for your rose that makes your rose so important." This emphasizes that relationships gain value through the time and care we invest in them.

The fox also imparts a crucial lesson about responsibility: "Men have forgotten this truth," said the fox. "But you must not forget it. You become responsible, forever, for what you have tamed. You are responsible for your rose."

## The Deeper Meaning of Taming

Looking at the etymology, the French word "apprivoiser" (to tame) originates from the Latin word "prīvō," which means to release or free. This is practically the opposite of being domesticated or made obedient. And when the prince and the fox become tamed, they're essentially freed from their loneliness and unhappiness. In a sense, befriending someone—seeing the best in them and caring for them— sets them free and helps them grow in significant ways.

## The Universal Application

The collection of allegories in The Little Prince effectively illustrates the necessity of social relationships within civilization. In order to form companionships, an individual may have to relinquish independence and self-centricity, similar to the wildness of the fox. However, forming connections produces benefits for individual's perspectives. Deep social relationships allow individuals to understand one another's being and value each other's inward individuality. After the little prince tamed the fox, the prince understood the value of his own rose and his own fox, even though both are outwardly commonplace. The time and care the little prince invested in his relationships allowed for the appreciation of the beauty in those he tamed.

The fox's teachings in "The Little Prince" present a profound philosophy about human connections, emphasizing that true friendship requires time, patience, and mutual commitment. Through the process of "taming," we create unique bonds that transform our perception of the world and give meaning to otherwise ordinary things. The fox's wisdom reminds us that the most valuable aspects of life—love, friendship, and human connection—are invisible to the eye but deeply felt by the heart.
